intro: Acacia caboverdeana, commonly known as the Cape Verde acacia, is a shrub native to the Cape Verde Islands. It is characterized by its slender, spiny branches and small, bipinnate leaves. The plant produces yellow flowers in compact, globular clusters, which are followed by flat, leathery pods. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, showing adaptability to poor soils. Its ecological importance includes providing habitat and food for local wildlife.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia caboverdeana is primarily native to Cape Verde. It is commonly found in the arid and semi-arid regions of the archipelago. This species thrives in coastal areas and sandy soils. It plays an important role in the local ecosystem and is often used for its hardy characteristics. The plant is well adapted to the harsh climate of Cape Verde.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acacia caboverdeana was mainly introduced to stabilize soil and prevent erosion in arid and semi-arid regions. It is commonly found in areas with low rainfall and poor soil quality. This plant is valued for its ability to thrive in harsh environmental conditions. It has been used in reforestation projects and as a source of timber and fuelwood. Its introduction has helped in restoring degraded lands in several parts of Africa.
